message_1: Determine the analytic continuation of the function $f(z) = \sqrt{z-1}$ along the path $z(t) = t^2+1$ starting at $z(0) = 1$.
message_2:
To find the analytic continuation of the function $f(z) = \sqrt{z-1}$ along the path $z(t) = t^2 + 1$, we first need to parametrize the path and then substitute it into the function.

The path is given by $z(t) = t^2 + 1$. We want to find $f(z(t))$:

$$
f(z(t)) = \sqrt{z(t) - 1} = \sqrt{t^2 + 1 - 1} = \sqrt{t^2}.
$$

Now, we need to be careful with the square root function, as it has two branches. Since we are starting at $z(0) = 1$, we choose the positive branch of the square root:

$$
f(z(t)) = \sqrt{t^2} = |t|.
$$

This is the analytic continuation of the function $f(z) = \sqrt{z-1}$ along the path $z(t) = t^2 + 1$ starting at $z(0) = 1$.
